abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Post-Accession Rural
            Support Project for Poland were as follows: outcomes were
            moderately satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            low or negligible, the Bank performance was moderately
            unsatisfactory, and the Borrower performance was moderately
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: virtually all
            project stakeholders pointed out that in reality there were
            two separate projects under one heading, and that it would
            have been better to implement them as separate projects. To
            begin with, it was impossible to find a project coordinator
            or a task team leader (TTL) with all the competences
            required to do a good job on both of the main components,
            and while team work can help compensate for missing
            competencies, the final responsibility should rest on
            someone who has a complete grasp of all project components.
            In particular, the Agricultural Social Insurance Fund (KRUS)
            administrative reform component will have required a TTL
            with an information technology, or IT specialization.
            Fortunately, the Ministry of Labor and Social Policy (MLSP)
            never assigned someone to specifically manage the component,
            and the very competent KRUS staffs responsible for project
            implementation were given much autonomy, including direct
            access to Bank staff, which certainly allowed for smoother
            implementation. But one can easily imagine a case in which
            the official implementing agency would not be as flexible
            (or practical) and insist on keeping a tight control over
            all project aspects, including matters on which it is
            ill-equipped to work. A number of stakeholders interviewed
            during the ICR mission noted that this represented a
            shortcoming, because poverty and unemployment were often at
            the root of social exclusion. An operation to tackle social
            inclusion in a comprehensive way should also include a
            component specifically targeting employment creation, at
            least in contexts such as Poland's.

repnme.cdata!:
Helping Poland's communities break
            through barriers of poverty and isolation

abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile talks about helping
            Poland's communities break through the barriers of
            poverty and isolation. Poland's economy has grown in
            the past decade and many Poles were well off, but large
            parts of the country remained poor particularly in rural
            areas. Poland's Post Accession Rural Support Project
            piloted a new approach in working with socially marginalized
            and excluded people through social integration efforts at
            the local municipality level. It has drawn together local
            government and an innovative and creative coalition of
            public and civil society agencies to improve social service
            delivery for tackling social exclusion. As a result,
            communities have been strengthened, relationships fostered,
            minds broadened and society's marginalized engaged.

Helping Poland's communities break

repnme.cdata!:
Poland - Post-Accession Rural Support
            Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The Post-Accession Rural Support Project
            (PARSP) for Poland will: (i) increase social inclusion in
            rural underdeveloped gminas by enhancing the capacity of
            local governments to identify, plan, and execute social
            protection strategies through a Social Inclusion Program
            (SIP); and (ii) support agricultural insurance fund (KRUS)
            reform by enhancing the efficiency of the KRUS Agency,
            through strengthening its administrative and analytic
            capacity and improving its management and decision making
            process. The closing date for the project will be extended
            from June 30, 2011 until December 30, 2011. The extension is
            necessary to ensure that the functionality of component A of
            the project - the integrated farmers' social insurance
            (KRUS) system architecture be secured. KRUS administration
            reform implementation is proceeding satisfactorily and the
            most critical sub-component, the workflow system, is planned
            to be completed before June 30, 2011. However, two packages
            - management support system and archival system - have
            entailed complex procurement processes and timeframes for
            their implementation now extend beyond the current
            project's closing date. Procurement due diligence and
            support for each of these packages has required supplemental
            support and in the case of the Archive component,
            re-tendering. This second extension of the project closing
            date is necessary to ensure that the remaining component
            implementation is completed and that full functionality and
            integration of the KRUS system can be achieved. The Borrower
            has in place an action plan to complete the project by the
            end of the extension period.

Poland - Post-Accession Rural
            Support Project : restructuring (Vol. 2) : Data sheet

repnme.cdata!:
Poland - Post-Accession Rural Support
            Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The Post-Accession Rural Support Project
            (PARSP) for Poland will: (i) increase social inclusion in
            rural underdeveloped gminas by enhancing the capacity of
            local governments to identify, plan, and execute social
            protection strategies through a Social Inclusion Program
            (SIP); and (ii) support agricultural insurance fund (KRUS)
            reform by enhancing the efficiency of the KRUS Agency,
            through strengthening its administrative and analytic
            capacity and improving its management and decision making
            process. The reallocation is necessary to complete tasks
            under the social inclusion component of the operation
            covering local municipality leadership support and critical
            monitoring, dissemination and knowledge sharing and program
            evaluation actions. As agreed during the implementation
            support mission carried out in Poland in February, 2010,
            these tasks will encompass regional thematic conferences,
            continuance seminars, good practice training and promotion
            and publications, as per the agreed action plan. In
            addition, the reallocation will enable full provisioning for
            the beneficiary assessment programmed for the current
            calendar year and considered a key component for learning on
            results from PARSP investment on the social inclusion practice.
